content: I guess I'd like the mens take on this one. I've heard several women make statements such as they missed those month or two(or more) breaks from their husbands once they got out of the military. Of course that may sound like said person has a bad marriage to the ''outside'', but once you get accustomed to a certain lifestyle for a decade or two, it can take some getting used to. I personally think small breaks from each other helps keep the passion going, and adds a little excitement. Is the adjustment the same for the guys? "It is the weak who are cruel. Gentleness can only be expected from the strong" -- Leo Roskin

content: Bought, I'm not retired military, the longest Lora and I have been apart is two weeks. I was on a fishin trip in Montana. Lora missed me, I was too preoccupied with the fish! lol Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: Been retired for 15 months now. I don't miss the moving around and the TDYs at all. We finally bought a house, and some real furniture! It's great to lay down some roots and truly call somewhere "home."

content: After retiring, the wife and me found out we couldn't live together. So I let her have the house and I moved across town. Still best friends, just can't live together.
reply: After retiring, the wife and me found out we couldn't live together. So I let her have the house and I moved across town. Still best friends, just can't live together.
title: Married lifers(retired)

content: Well, I was the retiree and HE was the "adjustee." We bought a house, settled in, he already had a job and kept it, I found one. Over time ... I got restless. Had to re-arrange the furniture in lieu of a PCS. No TDYs. Few job-related trainings for either of us to take a break from each other - and we had taken separate vacations several times over the years - and, eventually, it sorta broke down. We wound up divorced. We probably would have done that years earlier had it not been for minor distractions like deployment to Desert Storm and such. I'd say prepare for the worst and hope for the best. If you're used to spending some time apart, then PLAN for it in the future. Your needs and feelings are not likely to change just because somebody's job does. It may take more careful budgeting, in these times, but it can be done. Good luck, amiga.

title: Married lifers(retired)

content: I have been retired for a lmost 10.5 years. When I first got out, it was different with no TDYs and such, but I was still working weird hours since the job I held required me to be on call 24/7 and the job the wife held had her working 3 weekends a month and 1 or 2 nights each week. After a couple of years, we felt like it was time for the moving van to show up and on to next place. That took a little getting used to. Now that we both have jobs that allow us more time together, it is great since it was a gradual progression getting to this point. Military to civilian is a bit of a shock (what the heck is business casual attire anyway?), but well worth it. As McGreer said getting to put down some roots and build equity is a good thing. Well that and the monthly check...
reply: I have been retired for a lmost 10.5 years. Now that we both have jobs that allow us more time together, it is great since it was a gradual progression getting to this point. Military to civilian is a bit of a shock (what the heck is business casual attire anyway?), but well worth it. As McGreer said getting to put down some roots and build equity is a good thing. Well that and the monthly check...
title: Married lifers(retired)

content: We have been retired and living in civilian life now for over 6 years. We both like it. I don't miss the deployments and little breaks in between. What I do miss is the fact that my two sons grew up and for the most part I missed alot of father-son time. I tried to make up for it when I returned from deployments, we would go on camping trips and little family get togethers, just us. We lived in Hawai'i the last seven years and those times were great. But now I plan to retire at 66 or 67 and enjoy my retirement. That is if I can retire then.

content: When my dad retires (not military but Sea Captain - ferries, tug boats, etc.. for over 40 years) mom was fine for about a month or two then she told him to go do volunteer work because he was cutting into her time, lol The funny thing is all of us kids were gone by then. she now sends him out to do grocery shopping, go see his friends, he volunteers at a Maritime Museum and their church.

content: I retired in '03. Had a 9-5 gig in San Diego for a bit. She seemed restless, asked about any travel opportunities i might have with my new job. To her disappointment i told her "No". I eventually quit that job, didn't really care for it anyway. In March 04 i took another contract gig, this time in Iraq. Been workin' here ever since. Everytime i come home, it's like the honeymoon all over again.

title: Married lifers(retired)

content: I retired from the Army after 24 years 6 months and 11 days in 1977. I have also retired from two other careers since retiring from the Army. I don't have a problem, my wife does. She misses the NCO Wives Club activities, the Generals wife tea meetings and my overseas trips and TDY's. My after Army military contractor careers also required overseas travel on a regular basis. My last retirement was March of 2007 and my stay at home is starting to work on my wife's nerves. Oh, we have been married 48 years.
reply: I retired from the Army after 24 years 6 months and 11 days in 1977. I have also retired from two other careers since retiring from the Army. I don't have a problem, my wife does.
